content: The Act may be cited as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress finds that protecting citizens from armed violent criminals is crucial for public safety. Banning specific firearms does not deter criminals, so the focus should be on arresting, convicting, and incarcerating them effectively. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of this Act. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets. The task force will focus on severe punishment as a deterrent and consider Federal and State laws for apprehension and prosecution. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of this Act, focusing on severe punishment as a deterrent. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to address the effectiveness of laws, resources, nature of violent crime, and limited Federal involvement in prosecution. Monthly reports on defendants charged with violent crimes are required by the Attorney General. The Attorney General mandates monthly reports from US attorneys on defendants charged with violating specific sections of the US Code. Additionally, semi-annual compilations of this data and reports on waivers granted must be submitted to Congress. US attorneys can request waivers from the Attorney General for certain requirements. The Attorney General requires monthly reports from US attorneys on defendants charged with specific US Code violations. US attorneys can request waivers for certain requirements, with the Attorney General having the authority to grant waivers based on established guidelines considering the number of assistant US attorneys and the level of violent crime in the district. The Attorney General requires monthly reports from US attorneys on defendants charged with specific US Code violations. US attorneys can request waivers based on the level of violent crime in the district. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as a person accused of violating specific sections of the US Code. This section will expire after a 5-year period following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF THE PROHIBITIONS RELATING TO SEMIAUTOMATIC ASSAULT WEAPONS AND LARGE CAPACITY AMMUNITION FEEDING DEVICES. Amendments are made to various sections of the United States Code, including the repeal of certain prohibitions related to semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices. MANDATORY PRISON TERMS for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing or brandishing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking crime. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, while brandishing leads to 10 years imprisonment. The revised Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, mandates prison terms for using a firearm during a crime. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing leads to 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure results in 20 years. Additional sentences apply for specific types of firearms. The revised Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, mandates prison terms for using a firearm during a crime. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing leads to 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure results in 20 years. Additional sentences apply for specific types of firearms, with imprisonment for 30 years for machineguns or destructive devices equipped with firearm silencers or mufflers. Subsequent convictions result in additional sentences of not less than 20 years for possession and brandishing during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The revised Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, mandates prison terms for using a firearm during a crime. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing leads to 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure results in 20 years. Additional sentences apply for specific types of firearms, with imprisonment for 30 years for machineguns or destructive devices equipped with firearm silencers or mufflers. Subsequent convictions result in additional sentences of not less than 25 years for brandishing and 30 years for discharging with intent to injure during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The court shall not impose probation or concurrent sentences for firearm-related offenses. Life imprisonment is mandated for using a machinegun, destructive device, or firearm silencer. No release during the imposed imprisonment term. Passed the House of Representatives on March 22, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
